duction coil, was discharged be

56. In resuming we are struck by the va 
riety of appearences presented by igni 
ted vapour of carbon when submitted 
to spectral analysis under different con
ditions. But, whatever may be this vari 
ety, it is impossible not to admit, that 
all, or nearly all various types of spec 
tra we described are derived from the 
same source. We may distinguish 
four such types: 1t the bands, especially 
seen when the flame of cyanogen is fed 
by air, 2ly the particular distribution of 
light and shadow near H[beta], when the 
flame of olefiant gas is fed by oxygen,
3d the large fields shadowed by transversal
